awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Metapopulation Modeling to Develop Strategies to Reduce COVID-19 Transmission in Public Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
The COVID-19 pandemic presents an unprecedented challenge to public and private institutions to safely reopen public spaces, including workspaces and schools. However, we have little guidance on how to manage the use of shared spaces in light of a highly transmissible, but invisible, pathogen. The fundamental aim of this project is to better understand how SARS-CoV-2 spreads in built environments. Predictions generated by mathematical modeling will be experimentally tested using a surrogate non-pathogenic virus. This project presents a new paradigm where the likelihood of infected individuals being present, the amount and manner of viral shedding, the locations of viruses over time, and the usage-needs of a location provide for a major advancement in the assessment of public space occupancy and usage. The ultimate goal is to develop practices capable of limiting virus transmission and meeting the current worldwide challenge to public health. Recommendations will resemble established building and fire codes, which regulate how space is allotted per occupant based upon design and usage requirements; our analyses will generate a “COVID Code” that can be generalized for use during future outbreaks. This research will also provide training opportunities for students and postdoctoral scholars.  

A recently developed computational model (the Ephemeral Island Metapopulation Model (EIMM)) that applies metapopulation theory to explain how pathogens persist in hospital environments will be revised to address the spatial spread of SARS-CoV-2 within built environments. The EIMM defines aspects of the built environment as distinct habitable zones of occupancy (“demes”) in much the same manner as human hosts are considered, but these demes have their own biological parameters relevant to the survival and transmission of SARS-CoV-2. The number and size of both living and non-living demes, instead of human hosts alone, are used to model size and location of pathogen populations using ecologically relevant parameters, such as growth rate, population size, and carrying capacity. An enveloped bacteriophage phi6 will be used to validate model expectations as well as test control strategies in real environments such as classrooms. The goal is to test which interventions suggested by the EIMM minimize opportunities for phage phi6 spread in shared spaces, and this information can be adapted to provide estimates of how various interventions would affect SARS-CoV-2 persistence and transmission.

This RAPID award is made by the Ecology and Evolution of Infectious Diseases Program in the Division of Environmental Biology, using funds from the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The COVID-19 pandemic presented an unprecedented challenge to public and private institutions to safely reopen public spaces, including workspaces and schools. There was little guidance on how to manage the use of shared spaces considering the emergence of a highly transmissible, but invisible, pathogen, the SARS-CoV-2 virus. We aimed to use a combination of modeling and experimental methods in a real world setting of our university classrooms to study a surrogate virus to better understand how SARS-Cov-2 spreads in these types of environments. Our goal was to help develop practices capable of limiting virus transmission and meeting the current worldwide challenge to public health. Lastly, we planned to disseminate the information we found to public and private institutions so that they might minimize opportunities for virus transmission as the world emerges from the shutdown. The project was timely in that we had an immediate need to make recommendations to our colleagues regarding functional interventions for schools and businesses, as there was and continues to be communal discussion concerning how best to operate in the face of a highly transmissible airborne virus. We aimed to provide concrete guidelines to address questions such as: How to spatially arrange workplaces? How long does SARS-CoV-2 remain in a classroom? How to adjust cleaning schedules? What density of personnel is safe? Should personnel wear PPE? Should HVAC mediated airborne spread be accounted for? How should surface cleaning be prioritized? While physical distancing and mask wearing may help mitigate short-range transmission, what is the extent of long-range transmission in closed spaces where a pathogen remains suspended in the air?

 

We have developed a method to detect viable virus particles by using an aerosolized bacteriophage Phi6 in combination with its host Pseudomonas phaseolicola, which when seeded on agar plates acts as a virus detector that can be placed at a range of distances away from an aerosol-generating source. By applying this method, we could detect viable phage particles at distances of up to 18 feet away from the source within 15 min of exposure in a classroom equipped with a state-of-the-art HVAC system and determined that increasing the relative humidity beyond 40% significantly reduces dispersal. Our method, which can be further modified for use with other virus/host combinations, quantifies airborne transmission in the built environment and can thus be used to set safety standards for room capacity and to ascertain the efficacy of interventions in closed spaces of specified sizes and intended uses. Along with the development of this model, we have also developed a website COVIDCODE.net, which describes the project and provides resources and materials to support public awareness and understanding of SARS-CoV-2 transmission and biology. The project has also expanded to include investigation of airborne bacterial prevalence in classroom settings and modeling using the data generated from the experiments. Several undergraduate students have been trained as well as one master's student and two postdoctoral fellows. The work has generated several presentations including posters and oral presentations at local and national conferences as well as a published paper.
